overview_of_class: The goal for this course is to present an introduction to the analysis of financial data. The topics to be covered include models for returns, portfolio theory, the capital asset pricing model, and factor models. The emphasis will be on understanding the basic methods of finance and using these methods to guide the statistical analysis of financial data.
name: Introduction to the Analysis of Financial Data
title: WCAS STAT 365-0-1 Introduction to the Analysis of Financial Data

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The goal for this course is to present an introduction to the analysis of financial data. The topics to be covered include models for returns, portfolio theory, the capital asset pricing model, and factor models. The emphasis will be on understanding the basic methods of finance and using these methods to guide the statistical analysis of financial data.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Math 240 and at least two courses in Statistics. Ideally, these two courses will include Stat 320-2 or the equivalent.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. Understand the nature and properties of return data used in finance

2. Develop and interpret statistical models for financial data

3. Understand the role of statistical concepts in evaluating assets

4. Use mathematical and statistical techniques to construct optimal portfolios

5. Use statistical software to analyze financial data, estimate parameters of return distributions, and to draw appropriate conclusions

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on 4-5 homework assignments (25%), two exams (25% each), and a take-home final exam (25%).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
The text for the course is a draft of the manuscript "Statistical Methods in Finance: An Introduction by T. A. Severini. Instructions for obtaining the text will be given in class.

We will use the statistical software R, which is available at https://www.r-project.org

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: To contact Professor Thomas Severini: severini@northwestern.edu, or Department of Statistics, 2006 Sheridan Road, room 32, Evanston campus.
